spanishExample: ¡El maestro tiene seis años, así que sí es joven!
englishTranslation: The teacher is 6 years old, so he IS young!
vocabIncluded: tener X años: to be X years old (idiom)

spanishExample: El policía nos parece el jefe.
englishTranslation: The police officer seems to us like the boss.
vocabIncluded: nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")
parece: seems, he/she/it seems (Parecer, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: El profesor parece un estudiante.
englishTranslation: The professor looks like a student.
vocabIncluded: parece: seems, he/she/it seems (Parecer, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Espero que parezca que tenemos siete años.
englishTranslation: I hope it looks like we are 7 years old.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
espero:  hope/wait/expect, I  hope/wait/expect  (Esperar, present, 1st person)
parezca: seem, he/she/it seem (Parecer, subjunctive, 3rd person)
tener X años: to be X years old (idiom)

spanishExample: Llama al agente mañana.
englishTranslation: Call the agent tomorrow.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun

spanishExample: Los dos se llaman José y puede parecer genial.
englishTranslation: They are both called José, and it might seem great.
vocabIncluded: llaman: call, they call (Llamar, present, 3rd person plural)
llamarse: any use of to call with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "to be named"

spanishExample: Los niños le parecen mal al maestro.
englishTranslation: The kids seem unwell to the teacher(m).
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
parecen: seem, they seem (Parecer, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Me gustaría ir, aunque parezca que estamos juntos.
englishTranslation: I would like to go, even if it looks like we are together.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
gustaría: would like, he/she/it would like (Gustar, conditional, 3rd person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
parezca: seem, he/she/it seem (Parecer, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Me gustaría llamar al doctor, es importante.
englishTranslation: I would like to call the doctor, it’s important.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun
gustaría: would like, he/she/it would like (Gustar, conditional, 3rd person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Me ha parecido que no llamó.
englishTranslation: It has seemed to me that she didn’t call.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
llamó: called, he/she/it called (Llamar, preterite, 3rd person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Me llamo Antonio y mi hermana se llama Julia.
englishTranslation: My name is Antonio and my sister’s name is Julia.
vocabIncluded: llama: calls, he/she/it calls (Llamar, present, 3rd person)
llamarse: any use of to call with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "to be named"
llamo: call, I call (Llamar, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Me parece que era el presidente.
englishTranslation: It seems to me like it was the president.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
parece: seems, he/she/it seems (Parecer, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No te preocupes, voy a llamar a la puerta.
englishTranslation: Don’t worry, I’m going to knock on the door.
vocabIncluded: llamar a la puerta: to call/knock on the door (idiom)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Nos vamos a llamar ‘los jóvenes’ y nos gusta.
englishTranslation: We’re going to be named ‘the young ones’ and we like it.
vocabIncluded: gusta: likes, he/she/it likes (Gustar, present, 3rd person)
llamarse: any use of to call with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "to be named"
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Nunca llamas porque eres joven y malo.
englishTranslation: You never call because you’re young and mean.
vocabIncluded: llamas: call, you call (Llamar, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Parece que está loco.
englishTranslation: It seems like he is crazy.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
parece: seems, he/she/it seems (Parecer, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Parece que te llaman todos los días.
englishTranslation: It seems like they call you every day.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
llaman: call, they call (Llamar, present, 3rd person plural)
parece: seems, he/she/it seems (Parecer, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Parecían tristes y el rey lo sabe.
englishTranslation: They seemed sad and the king knows it.

spanishExample: Pareces viejo, ¿cómo te llamas?
englishTranslation: You seem old, what’s your name?
vocabIncluded: cómo: adverb meaning "how?" in a question or implied question
llamarse: any use of to call with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "to be named"
llamas: call, you call (Llamar, present, 2nd person)
pareces: seem, you seem (Parecer, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Parecía extraño que no hubiera llamado.
englishTranslation: It seemed strange that she hadn’t called.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
hubiera: "were to have", "he/she/it were to have" (Haber, past subjunctive, 3rd person)
parecía: seemed, he/she/it seemed (Parecer, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Se ha llamado así toda su vida.
englishTranslation: He has been named that his whole life.
vocabIncluded: así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
llamarse: any use of to call with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "to be named"

spanishExample: Se llamó Esperanza, pero no nos importa.
englishTranslation: She was named Esperanza, but we don’t care.
vocabIncluded: importa: matters, he/she/it matters (Importar, present, 3rd person)
llamarse: any use of to call with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "to be named"
llamó: called, he/she/it called (Llamar, preterite, 3rd person)
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: Si no te llamo hoy, te llamaré mañana.
englishTranslation: If I don’t call you today, I will call you tomorrow.
vocabIncluded: llamaré: will call, I will call (Llamar, future, 1st person)
llamo: call, I call (Llamar, present, 1st person)
